Comment: tɛtɛrɛ=cut hair, sɔri=cut meat, rekise=cut wood or bone
ara=down, cf. malu cane=fall outside, malu cane=fall inside
uta=hit (on  strings/cover of drum); tipal = drum; aija uta=rain pours down
a-hani=my possession, e-heni=your possession, afi-heni=our possession, i-hini=our (excl) possession, tawa(?) hini=their possession
utuɁɛ = also 'three' and 'plant rice' because maximally  3 seeds are planted together in one hole (at 6:05 mns).
lɔiasu = boat, hiapɛ = go on a boat
amuseke=to smell, stink; amuhɔru=smto smell something
raɁu wahu=wash dishes, lau pahale=wash clothes
raɁu wahu=wash dishes, lau pahale=wash clothes
uta=hit/pull strings (?), also used for playing guitar
e.g. ana Lospalos naɁe = I'm in Lospalos
written by speaker as 'acha', contrasts with 'aca tapin' = smoke
lɔhɔ also means: pen (kandang), e.g. pipi lɔhɔ=goat pen
ucanit=kill & divide, eme=take; "ucanit eme tupura mɔkɔr ina": tupura mokor 'bride', ina 'give', 'dowry given by the bride'
sapi aku=cow shit, arapɔu aku=buffalo shit, pipi aku=goat shit
Beginning of third clip: discussion of minimal pair aca=wood vs atɕa (tara leu) =chicken.
ɔlɔ=bird,  atɕa=lay eggs, atɕa tara leu=chicken
'ɔcawa=the owner/creator, uru'watɕu= the one who is above everything
'ɔcawa=the owner/creator, uru'watɕu= the one who is above everything
poukala=pebbles, mokor = small. At 14:30 speaker elaborates on the plural suffix and provides contrasting examples.
kuru=hole in e.g. nose, or in the ground (e.g. a well), papane=small hole in e.g. a tyre
kuru=hole in e.g. nose, or in the ground (e.g. a well), papane=small hole in e.g. a tyre
hikari=knife, moko=small; hikari moko-r = small knives; hikari lafica-r = big knives.
mautule = lazy person; mau=not want, tule/cule=lazy
pira=edge; tahi ɔɁɔ pira= sea shore
pai=pig, musu=lick; myth that if a lizard just licks a pig, the pig will get pregnant
ava=penis (human), fula=penis (animal), eg. kuca fula = horse penis
ava=penis (human), fula=penis (animal), eg. kuca fula = horse penis
ale pala=rice field; cele pala = corn field; pala=field to plant crops, e.g. tomat pala=tomato field; modo pala = vegetable garden
ɛtɛ =tree, larin=root; mu: larin= banana root
